title: 113_hr2199
content: The Flood Insurance Implementation Reform Act of 2013 delays required premium adjustments upon remapping for 3 years and delays full actuarial rates for newly purchased properties for 5 years. The Flood Insurance Implementation Reform Act of 2013 delays premium adjustments upon remapping for 3 years and actuarial rates for newly purchased properties for 5 years. It also requires adequate progress on the construction of flood protection systems. SEC. 4 amends the National Flood Insurance Act to exclude federal funding from consideration in determining adequate progress on flood protection systems. SEC. 5 addresses communities restoring disaccredited flood protection systems. SEC. 5 amends the National Flood Insurance Act to apply to communities restoring flood protection systems previously accredited for 100-year flood protection. Section 100236 of the Biggert-Waters Flood Insurance Reform Act of 2012 is amended to include provisions regarding funding sources for the National Flood Insurance Fund. The Administrator may use other available amounts to carry out the section. Additionally, an alternative option is provided if the Administrator determines the need for it. If the report required under subsection (c) cannot be submitted on time, the Administrator will notify the relevant committees of an alternative method to gather the necessary information. The Administrator will then submit the gathered information using the alternative method within 180 days of the notification. Upon submission of required information, the subsection (c) requirement will be considered satisfied. SEC. 7. Mapping of non-structural flood mitigation features. Section 100216 of the Biggert-Waters Flood Insurance Reform Act of 2012 is amended to include areas protected by non-structural flood mitigation features. Subsection (d)(1) is also revised to redesignate subparagraphs. The Biggert-Waters Flood Insurance Reform Act of 2012 is amended to include areas protected by non-structural flood mitigation features. Subsection (d)(1) is revised to work with States, local communities, and property owners to identify specific areas and features.
